fields.headline: Cheltenham Diary
fields.bodyText: · On a day when the French-bred Hors La Loi III won the Champion Hurdle, it was fitting that the directors of Pau racecourse, the second biggest jumping track in France in the shadow of the Pyrenees, came over to Cheltenham to plug their region's delights. "Many English racing professionals have come over to buy horses from us," said Pau's François Jussarieu as he distributed reviving glasses of the sweet Jurançon white wine and blocks of foie gras to investigative reporters. "Now we want ordinary racegoers to enjoy our region too." They certainly will if British horses go over there and win at 10-1. · Several lifetimes of Festival savvy was on parade at the official reception to mark the 75th anniversary of the Champion Hurdle, including the jockey who rode Persian War to a hat-trick in 1968-69-70, Jimmy Uttley, and Mick Kinane's father Tommy who won on Monksfield in 1978. Also there was the debonair Frenchman Alec Head, who rode Le Paillon into second place in the 1947 race and then went on to become one of the great Flat trainers. Head had a few words for the anglais who have been making unflattering remarks about the French jockeys riding at Prestbury Park this week. "All our riders will do their very best," said Head. "And I'm sure all British ex-jockeys and trainers still believe they always did their best when riding at Longchamp, Chantilly and Auteuil." Touché. · The franc is no more, ditto the Irish punt, but the Tote was keeping an arm's-length approach to this filthy euro lucre. The Nanny advised that Irish or French punters wishing to bet in their new currency should hand in euros and receive Tote betting vouchers in exchange.
